captions.text:
John: Gooood Morning, Hank, it's Tuesday.
Wait, it's Tuesday. That means that I am no

longer for the United States. I am now all
in for Mexico! Hank, as you know I am auctioning

off my World Cup support for Sarcoma research
- link in the doobly-doo. Every time you donate

$1, I donate 3, and in total we've now raised
more than $55,000 to fight Sarcoma, which

is so awesome. Hey, why are you only gesticulating
with one hand? Well, funny story...

So Hank, as you know I am a retired semi-professional
FIFA player. For years, I uploaded my FIFA

videos to YouTube, people watched them, advertising
revenue, etc. But a while ago, I decided to

retire from professional FIFA playing because
I'm older now and the physical and emotional

strain had just gotten to be too much. I decided
I had to play just for the love of the game,

for the love of the pixels. So all the money
we make now goes to an actual football club,

AFC Wimbledon, owned by its fans, the first
football club to come out against homophobia
in England; they're just amazing.

Right, okay Hank, so if you're like me and
you're not actually very good at FIFA it's

not enough to like press the joystick in the
right directions and hit the right buttons.

You have to create a loving, supportive environment
for your team made of pixels so that they

feel comfortable scoring. Now for me a big
part of that is yelling at the screen, sometimes

like pulling this way when I want them to
go that way, but it also involves some singing,

and then when they score, I want to celebrate
with them! All of this is to say, Hank, that

recently, the AFC Wimbledon Wimbly Womblys
scored a goal so beautiful, so amazing that

I did what any manager would do: I shot up
my arms and I shouted, "AFC Wimbledon!" Only

I did it with both arms, because that was
back when I could move both of my shoulders.

That's right Hank, I shot my right arm into
the air after scoring a goal in a video game

and seriously injured my shoulder. How seriously?
Not yet clear, waiting for some test results.

How do you injure yourself playing a video
game?! Actually, no, I did not injure myself

playing a video game. I injured myself celebrating
my success playing a video game.

So yeah, Hank, this whole experience has made
me realize something: I'm old. I have a lot

of gray hair over here, but in the two months
of promoting The Fault in Our Stars movie

I got a lot of new gray hair up in here. Now
Hank, thankfully you're not old and, as far

as I can tell, you never will be. You have
the body of a man in his 30's, but the personality

and face of an excited 9-year-old, which I
mean as a compliment. So Hank, hopefully you'll

be the brother who doesn't get old and, like,
stays hip and cool, but Nerdfighters, I am

getting old. In fact, I'm older than I was
when I started this video. I'm having a little

bit of a crisis about being old because I
wanna be a Nerdfighter for the rest of my

life, so I'm hoping there are other old Nerdfighters.
I think there are. But mostly I just wanted

to say I hope we can still be friends even
though I am old and shoulder-less.

Again, link in the doobly-doo to our World
Cup fundraiser. You can follow along the World
Cup with me at my sports Twitter, @sportswithjohn.

Hank, don't play video games too strenuously.
I will see you on Friday.

comments.text: LOL,﻿

comments.text:
I'm an old nerd fighter! which is why i'll never go to a show or meetup, no 
one wants to be the oldest guy in the room lol.﻿
comments.author: emily rose

comments.text:
I may or may not have been alive since the 70's...and I once closed a

comments.author: RandomSandra

comments.text: Hurt yourself patting yourself on the back.﻿
comments.author: TJ Anderson

comments.text:
LOL, my sympathy. I am 53 years young. I started riding motorbikes when I 
was 7. They have kept me young, like Peter Pan. But in the middle of 2012 I 
dumped my beautiful black ZX14 and then tried to save it from harm, by 
sliding into the earthen bank first and trying to cushion its impact. That 
accounted for the pelvis in about 17 pieces and the mechano that now holds 
it together. The brain injury, which also ruined my nice new flashy Arai, 
worth about a thousand dollars, that was probably the ground, some place. I 
don't actually remember any of this, I heard about it later.

You got hurt playing a video game. At least you remember what happened. I 
got hurt riding a bike, and I lost about 9 weeks. The last thing I can 
remember before it, was about 4 hours before it.

I am sympathetic. Get well soon. DFTBA.﻿

comments.text:
I'm a tall individual, I was playing just dance in the living room, threw 
my arm up for an epic dance move, aaaaannd hit the ceiling fan... After 
noting that I was bleeding, not thinking it was serious I called to my 
mom(I was 15 at the time) "mom, I think I hurt myself!" she told me I would 
need stitches(to which I freaked out and protested to.) so.. In short.. I 
had to get 12 stitches in my finger, which ended up permanently scarring 
the side... From playing just dance 2...﻿

comments.text:
i have osteogenesis imperfecta i know it sounds like a spell in harry 
potter, but it basically means my bones are like glass and lets not get 
started on all the other impaction of having a default collagen gene. but 
this resulted in me at the rip old age of 22 selling my wii as every time i 
played it i would end up in the emergency room. like i mean i broke my 
fingers on Christmas eve playing bolling and i dislocated my sholder from a 
sarwd game, and i couldnt use my hands from the vibration after playing 
supermario galaxic, you are only as old as you let yourself(sorry for the 
spelling mistakes). ﻿

comments.author: Sean a

comments.text:
Dear John,
Though saying that I am a fifteen year old nerd fighter is rather 
detrimental to your situation, and probably discredits what I am about to 
say. Being a nerd fighter holds no age restriction. In fact being a nerd 
fighter requires being a grown up in ways of thinking and understanding 
society. When you said I hope "I can still be a nerd fighter" it brought me 
back to when you said "if you want to be a nerd fighter, you probably are 
one" As long as you have a desire to make the world better you are a 
nerdfighter, even if you do injure your shoulder celebrating your video 
game achievements. As long as you are yourself, even if you are old (which 
you are not) you will forever be one the greatest nerdfighters of all
I would say DFTBA, however I feel that awesomeness is intrinsic to your 
nature therefore forgetting to be awesome is not a problem for you. I 
apologize for the lateness of this comment and I hope you read this
- Julianne ﻿

comments.author: Kristian Lyhne-nielsen

comments.text:
I broke my arm turning around to talk to a friend during a picnic. I broke 
my big toe kicking a balloon (and it only hit the balloon, but for some 
reason, the balloon didn't pop and... physics). I broke my pink and ring 
fingers giving a confused, half-hearted high-five to someone who wanted to 
congratulate me for standing my ground well when I was being bullied. All 
before graduating middle school.
Then I broke my nose walking into a pole on my first night of college.
I have not broken anything else yet. Knock on wood. John, it's not because 
you're old. It's because of... well... common physics and flawed biology 
(and maybe a little intelligence, or lack thereof). D:﻿

comments.text:
I'm trying to take in that John Green is rich enough to donate upwards of 
$41,250 to sarcoma research, and that other NerdFighters have collectively 
donated $13,750... the difference of which is the median annual income of 
many people (in low-income jobs) in the United Kingdom.

It is in fact higher than the annual income of people who work in the 
records departments of hospitals.﻿
